conclusion: To determine the difference in electric potential energy, consider the forces acting on the ball and the potential energy changes.
Electric potential energy of a charged particle in an electric field is given by U_PE = qE.
The ball is positively charged, so its charge q = +q.
The electric field E is directed horizontally.
Electric potential energy at point O is U_PE, O = +qE.
Kinetic energy of a particle is given by K = 1/2 mv^2.
Initial velocity v_0 is assumed constant.
Final velocity v can be found using v^2 = v_0^2 + 2ad.
Acceleration a is a = g sin(theta).
Distance d is the horizontal distance traveled by the ball, d = v_0 t.
Time t can be found using t = v_0 / (g sin(theta)).
Final velocity v is v = v_0 sin(theta).
Kinetic energy K at the highest point is K = 1/2 mv_0^2 sin^2(theta).
Change in electric potential energy Delta U_PE is Delta U_PE = U_PE, O - U_PE.
Difference in electric potential energy Delta U_PE is Delta U_PE = +qE - 1/2 mv_0^2 sin^2(theta).
The difference in electric potential energy of the small ball when it reaches the highest point compared to its electric potential energy at point O is +qE - 1/2 mv_0^2 sin^2(theta).
